item.title: World view: free climbing a giant redwood, Eureka, northern California
item.trailText: California’s giant redwoods are a natural wonder. In these breathtaking shots climber Chris Sharma scales a 77-metre-tall sequoia. The reason? Red Bull’s Giant Ascent project and a chance for biologists to check the 600-year-old tree’s health
item.standFirst: California’s huge redwood trees are a natural wonder. In these breathtaking shots, climber Chris Sharma scales a 77-metre-tall sequoia. The reason? Red Bull’s Giant Ascent project and a chance for biologists to check the 600-year-old tree’s health

displayImages.caption:
Many of us climbed trees as kids, but the Californian pro-climber Chris Sharma has taken the childhood pursuit to dizzying heights, scaling a huge redwood tree for a project called Giant Ascent.
• All photographs Keith Ladzinski/Red Bull
displayImages.altText: American climber Chris Sharma climbing a giant redwood
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Many of us climbed trees as kids, but the Californian pro-climber Chris Sharma has taken the childhood pursuit to dizzying heights, scaling a huge redwood tree for a project called Giant Ascent.
• All photographs Keith Ladzinski/Red Bull

displayImages.caption: The 34-year-old climber ascended the 77-metre redwood in Eureka, northern California, without ropes, climbing 50 metres up the bark before reaching the first branches.
displayImages.altText: Red Bull Giant Ascent 2015 USA
displayImages.cleanCaption: The 34-year-old climber ascended the 77-metre redwood in Eureka, northern California, without ropes, climbing 50 metres up the bark before reaching the first branches.

displayImages.caption: Sharma spent three days working on the project with a top rope, though he struggled to learn the route: the repetitive pattern in the bark was more disorientating than a cliff face. To rig the ropes, the support team had to shoot an arrow to the top using a high-powered crossbow.
displayImages.altText: Red Bull Giant Ascent 2015 USA
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sharma spent three days working on the project with a top rope, though he struggled to learn the route: the repetitive pattern in the bark was more disorientating than a cliff face. To rig the ropes, the support team had to shoot an arrow to the top using a high-powered crossbow.

displayImages.caption: The climb – which Sharma estimated as “at least a 9a” grade (for non-climbers, that’s pretty damn hard) – sent him high up into the canopy of the ancient forest.
displayImages.credit: Keith Ladzinski / Red Bull Content Pool
displayImages.altText: Red Bull Giant Ascent 2015 USA
displayImages.cleanCaption: The climb – which Sharma estimated as “at least a 9a” grade (for non-climbers, that’s pretty damn hard) – sent him high up into the canopy of the ancient forest.

displayImages.caption: The tree was estimated to be around 600-700 years old. One of the reasons Sharma set up the project was to support the work of Dr Anthony Ambrose and research associate Wendy Baxter from the University of California, Berkeley, who have been studying the trees for 18 years.
displayImages.credit: Keith Ladzinski / Red Bull Content Pool
displayImages.altText: Red Bull Giant Ascent 2015 USA
displayImages.cleanCaption: The tree was estimated to be around 600-700 years old. One of the reasons Sharma set up the project was to support the work of Dr Anthony Ambrose and research associate Wendy Baxter from the University of California, Berkeley, who have been studying the trees for 18 years.

displayImages.caption: Once at the top, Sharma collected samples to help Ambrose and Baxter analyse the health of the tree. The biologists are hoping to evaluate the impact of the current drought on the forests in the Santa Cruz Mountains.
displayImages.credit: Keith Ladzinski / Red Bull Content Pool
displayImages.altText: Red Bull Giant Ascent 2015 USA

item.title: Amur tiger relishes new home in Russian wild
item.trailText: An Amur tiger leaps to freedom after being given a new home in a mountainous region of east Russia
item.standFirst: An Amur tiger leaps to freedom after being given a new home in a mountainous region of east Russia. The tiger, named Uporny, was captured in November 2014 after being identified as a 'conflict' tiger. He was living in an area deplete of prey and had killed dogs to survive. Uporny's new home has a good supply of prey — and is home to a female Amur tiger

item.title: The moon is made of cheese? Ridiculous!
item.trailText: The irrepressible Jeremy Bumble explains how the moon was formed - video
item.standFirst: This week, the irrepressible Jeremy Bumble looks at how the moon was formed. With help from space scientist and Sky at Night presenter Maggie Aderin-Pocock, Jeremy discovers how our largest natural satellite got its appearance and why it is the Earth's best friend. Go Science! Special thanks to Richard Hunter, Jamie Maule-ffinch, Luke Roulstone, Phillippa Burgess, Stuart Mckechnie, Laura Mckechnie, UCL, Imperial College, Fabrics Galore, Vega Electronics

item.title: Jason Schwartzman talks about The Overnight
item.trailText: Jason Schwartzman on fatherhood, meeting new friends and the inevitable robot revolution that will make slaves of us all
item.standFirst:
The Overnight, starring Jason Schwartzman, Adam Scott and Taylor Schilling, is an independent comedy which explores what happens when two couples set up their own playdate, complete with weed-smoking, a lot of alcohol, and a lot of nudity.

Schwartzman gives the Guardian's Adam Gabbatt his views on fatherhood (good), meeting new friends as an adult (he doesn't, he has enough) and the risk of robots taking over the world (maybe they already have)

item.title: America’s 11 most endangered historic places
item.trailText: The National Trust for Historic Preservation has put the Grand Canyon, Miami’s Little Havana and a former gay nightclub in West Hollywood on its annual list of most endangered historic places. The list, made public late Tuesday night, seeks to bring attention to US sites of architectural, cultural and natural heritage that the Trust deems at risk due to neglect, development or an uncertain future.

item.title: Refugees escape Burundi's political violence – in pictures
item.trailText: Violence in Burundi started after President Pierre Nkurunziza announced his controversial bid for a third consecutive five-year term in office. The Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has said the violence in Burundi has forced more than 100,000 people to flee to neighbouring countries
item.standFirst: The head of Burundi’s influential rights group, Aprodeh, says at least 70 people, mostly civilians, have been killed and hundreds of others wounded following weeks of political unrest in the small, impoverished country in East Africa. The violence started after President Pierre Nkurunziza announced his controversial bid for a third consecutive five-year term in office. The Office of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) has said the violence in Burundi has forced more than 100,000 people to flee to neighbouring countries

item.title: The ingenious Delhi slum that scrapes by without toilets
item.trailText: At this year’s Glastonbury festival, WaterAid will once again be drumming up support for clean water programmes – like this one it has instituted in the Delhi slum of Safeda Basti
item.standFirst: At this year’s Glastonbury festival, WaterAid – one of the festival’s three main charity sponsors – will once again be handing out reusable water bottles and drumming up support for clean water programmes around the world. We take a look at its vital work in Safeda Basti, a Delhi slum whose 3,000 residents are cut off from the city’s water network

displayImages.caption: A woman combs a young girl’s hair in Safeda Basti, an informal settlement in the east of Delhi. Photograph: Adam Ferguson/WaterAid
displayImages.altText: A woman combs a young girl’s hair in Safeda Basti slum
displayImages.cleanCaption: A woman combs a young girl’s hair in Safeda Basti, an informal settlement in the east of Delhi.

displayImages.caption: Nankeshar Kumar Paswan, 18, from Safeda Basti, must often defecate by the side of the Yamuna River. Photograph: Adam Ferguson/WaterAid
displayImages.altText: Nankeshar Kumar Paswan, age 18, from Safeda Basti slum, uses the Yamuna River in New Delhi to defecate in.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nankeshar Kumar Paswan, 18, from Safeda Basti, must often defecate by the side of the Yamuna River.

displayImages.caption: Measuring just 150 metres by 75 metres, Safeda Basti houses 3,000 people, crammed into 574 small homes. Photograph: Nikhil Thakkar/WaterAid
displayImages.altText: With a population of 24,953,000 and counting, Delhi is a megacity and the second largest city in the world after Tokyo
displayImages.cleanCaption: Measuring just 150 metres by 75 metres, Safeda Basti houses 3,000 people, crammed into 574 small homes.

displayImages.caption: Until recently, no areas of the slum were connected to the sewage network, meaning many residents were forced to use the banks of the nearby river. Photograph: Nikhil Thakkar/Wateraid
displayImages.altText: An aerial view of Safeda Basti Slum
displayImages.cleanCaption: Until recently, no areas of the slum were connected to the sewage network, meaning many residents were forced to use the banks of the nearby river.

displayImages.caption: Men bathe and wash clothes in the open. Despite existing here for more than 20 years and having a lively electorate, the Safeda Basti community has never been formally recognised by the state. Photograph: Adam Ferguson/WaterAid
displayImages.altText: A man dries himself after bathing whilst others wash clothes in an open area in Safeda Basti slum
displayImages.cleanCaption: Men bathe and wash clothes in the open. Despite existing here for more than 20 years and having a lively electorate, the Safeda Basti community has never been formally recognised by the state.

displayImages.cleanCaption: With a population of 25 million and counting, Delhi is the second largest city after Tokyo.

displayImages.cleanCaption: A view of the Yamuna River where people openly defecate.

displayImages.caption: Sarita Devi stands near an open defecation site by an overpass. The international development charity WaterAid and its partner organisation Cure (Centre for Urban and Rural Excellence) have been organising for change in the slum. Photograph: Adam Ferguson/WaterAid
displayImages.altText: Sarita Devi, from Safeda Basti slum, stands near an open defecation site close to an overpass in New Delhi, India
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sarita Devi stands near an open defecation site by an overpass. The international development charity WaterAid and its partner organisation Cure (Centre for Urban and Rural Excellence) have been organising for change in the slum.

displayImages.caption: A man stands on a newly constructed sewerage chamber. After months of petitioning the authorities, WaterAid and Cure have successfully had 112 houses in Safeda Basti connected to Delhi’s sewer network. Photograph: Adam Ferguson/WaterAid
